2f0a00b899cfe8cef76f27891ef0185973fac583.title: Utah’s “bull manure” plan to increase gas prices in Idaho not well received - likely unconstitutional
2f0a00b899cfe8cef76f27891ef0185973fac583.description: "This is taxation without representation- something we fought a war over 250 years ago. I hope that Utah’s leaders realize that these dependencies run both ways, and as dependent as Idaho is on Utah for motor fuels, Utah is dependent on Idaho for water. I hope we don’t have to enter a cycle of mutual exploitation. I hope we can remain good friends and partners.”

20c00517dd564669fc026f31b1fecc21dbe1db21.title: Stanford’s Pulitzer Winner Jack Rakove on American Independence
20c00517dd564669fc026f31b1fecc21dbe1db21.description:
In this week’s episode of The Learning Curve, co-hosts Alisha Searcy and Massachusetts civics teacher Kelley Brown interview Pulitzer Prize-winning historian Jack Rakove, Coe Professor Emeritus at Stanford University. Prof. Rakove explores the origins of the American Revolution and U.S. Constitution through the lives of the nation’s Founding Era figures. Reflecting on young John Adams’ vivid depiction of his schoolhouse in colonial Massachusetts, Rakove offers context for the political and social landscape of the 18th-century America.

The post Stanford’s Pulitzer Winner Jack Rakove on American Independence appeared first on Pioneer Institute.

4397d45805633839103771afc1f3eaf168ee5ade.description:
The Virginia Institute for Public Policy has expressed concern over HJ6007, a proposed amendment to Virginia’s Constitution that would alter the state’s current redistricting process. The Institute emphasized that Virginia voters approved a bipartisan approach in 2020 to ensure fair and transparent elections for all citizens. Citing constitutional and procedural issues surrounding HJ6007, the Institute encourages lawmakers to uphold established safeguards that protect the integrity and balance of Virginia’s electoral system.

81027e82a7d2998a80e746a15b5b09ccb0f91382.title: On Warrants and Searches, A Man’s House Is His Castle
81027e82a7d2998a80e746a15b5b09ccb0f91382.description:
The Fourth Amendment and decades of case law make clear that law enforcement may not enter a residence for search or arrest without a warrant based on a statement of probable cause and signed by a neutral magistrate. Exceptions exist—exigent circumstances, hot pursuit, searches incident to arrest, plain view, consent—but the home remains the locus […]

The post On Warrants and Searches, A Man’s House Is His Castle appeared first on Pacific Research Institute.

95b5efe8383a08071bde2fef2271171f2b64c9f7.title: A Steady-State Budget in a Moment of Crisis
95b5efe8383a08071bde2fef2271171f2b64c9f7.description:
Governor Maura Healey’s fiscal year 2027 budget totals $62.8 billion, a 3.8 percent year-over-year increase. The budget avoids sweeping new initiatives and largely preserves existing structures. That might be defensible in a period of stability. It is indefensible now. 

The post A Steady-State Budget in a Moment of Crisis  appeared first on Pioneer Institute.

d18e6580b07cf1b19983a170d80d096179204732.description:
New Hampshire towns and cities are permitting more residential housing units than they have in years, which is great news. e7df36cbc3feaebb2d53c3c5e90c21ef04f2e667.title: A foolish law wages war against homemade shindigs
e7df36cbc3feaebb2d53c3c5e90c21ef04f2e667.description:
The law, passed in 2023, decrees that venues rented for private events at which the people holding the party bring their own alcohol can host only six such events a year, and only one a month — unless they prohibit bring-your-own drinks and instead get a liquor license like a tavern. Those are subject to strict quotas. Town board can simply refuse.

The post A foolish law wages war against homemade shindigs appeared first on Badger Institute.

9f05d0b104f9da8f0e082e987402cafd7bf68b50.title: Tax Relief, Spending Growth, and Restraint
9f05d0b104f9da8f0e082e987402cafd7bf68b50.description:
Governor Reynolds has proposed a $9.6 billion FY27 budget that modestly increases spending while education and health services, driven primarily by K-12 funding and Medicaid, continue to dominate state expenditures, consuming roughly 84 percent of the General Fund. Although Iowa is projecting a $1.2 billion revenue shortfall due to the fully phased-in 3.8 percent flat tax, this reflects a planned transition rather than a structural deficit, with the Taxpayer Relief Fund intentionally built to cushion revenues during tax reform. Iowa’s fiscal position remains strong with substantial reserves, but continued growth in major spending programs and federal uncertainty underscore the need for spending restraint and conservative budgeting.

The post Tax Relief, Spending Growth, and Restraint appeared first on ITR Foundation.
